subject: Aerospace Engineering
question_text: The product of the eigenvalues of the matrix [2 1 1; 1 3 1; 1 1 4] is
question_text_latex: \text{The product of the eigenvalues of the matrix } \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix} \text{ is}

tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the product of eigenvalues, which is equal to the determinant of the matrix. This is a straightforward numerical calculation.

answer_validation.reasoning:
The product of the eigenvalues of a square matrix is equal to its determinant. This is a fundamental property in linear algebra. Therefore, to find the product of the eigenvalues of the given matrix, we need to calculate its determinant.

Given matrix: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$

We calculate the determinant using cofactor expansion along the first row:
$\det(A) = 2 \times \det\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix} - 1 \times \det\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix} + 1 \times \det\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

First, calculate the 2x2 determinants:
1. $\det\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix} = (3 \times 4) - (1 \times 1) = 12 - 1 = 11$
2. $\det\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix} = (1 \times 4) - (1 \times 1) = 4 - 1 = 3$
3. $\det\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = (1 \times 1) - (3 \times 1) = 1 - 3 = -2$

Now, substitute these values back into the determinant calculation:
$\det(A) = 2 \times (11) - 1 \times (3) + 1 \times (-2)$
$\det(A) = 22 - 3 - 2$
$\det(A) = 19 - 2$
$\det(A) = 17$

Thus, the product of the eigenvalues of the given matrix is 17.

step_by_step: Step 1: Identify the key property: For any n x n matrix A, the product of its eigenvalues (counted with multiplicity) equals its determinant: $\det(A) = \prod_{i=1}^n \lambda_i$.
Step 2: Write down the given matrix: $A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 3 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$.
Step 3: Calculate the determinant of matrix A using the cofactor expansion or the rule for a 3x3 matrix.
Step 7: Conclude that the product of eigenvalues is equal to this determinant, which is 17.
formulas_used: \det\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix} = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)

topic.name: Linear Algebra - Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
topic.syllabus_ref: GATE AE Syllabus: Engineering Mathematics -> Linear Algebra -> Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors

essential: Calculation of determinant for a 3x3 matrix

Main Concept: requires: Definition of eigenvalues (roots of characteristic polynomial)
enables: Quick verification of eigenvalue calculations
enables: Understanding of matrix invertibility (zero eigenvalue)
Product of Eigenvalues: enables: Quick check for eigenvalue calculations

difficulty_factors: Requires recall of the property linking eigenvalues and determinant
Requires careful arithmetic in determinant calculation

textbook_references.author: B.S. Grewal
textbook_references.text_snippet: For any n x n matrix A with eigenvalues lambda_1, lambda_2, ..., lambda_n (counted with multiplicity), the product of its eigenvalues is equal to the determinant of the matrix A.

textbook_references.author: Erwin Kreyszig
textbook_references.text_snippet: The eigenvalues of a triangular matrix are the diagonal elements of the matrix.

video_references.professor: Prof. Sunita Gakkhar, Prof. H.G. Sharma, and Prof. Tanuja Srivastava
video_references.topic_covered: Product of eigenvalues equals determinant of matrix

video_references.professor: Prof. Sunita Gakkhar, Prof. H.G. Sharma, and Prof. Tanuja Srivastava

key_insights: The product of eigenvalues is the determinant, so no need to find individual eigenvalues.
The determinant of a triangular matrix is the product of its diagonal entries, but this matrix is not triangular, so direct 3x3 formula is used.

formulas_principles.name: Product of Eigenvalues Property
formulas_principles.conditions: For any square matrix A, eigenvalues counted with algebraic multiplicity.
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula that solves the problem directly.

formulas_principles.formula: \det\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix} = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)
formulas_principles.name: Determinant of a 3x3 Matrix
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute the numerical determinant.

formulas_principles.conditions: For an upper or lower triangular matrix A
formulas_principles.name: Eigenvalues of Triangular Matrices
formulas_principles.relevance: Shortcut for finding eigenvalues of the given matrix

industry_examples: In structural dynamics, eigenvalues represent natural frequencies, and the product of eigenvalues relates to system stability and determinant properties.
In control theory, eigenvalues determine system poles; their product can relate to the system's characteristic equation constant term.
specific_systems: Stability analysis of flight control systems
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Linear algebra, including eigenvalues and determinants, is fundamental in various aerospace engineering applications. For instance, in structural dynamics, eigenvalues represent natural frequencies of vibration. In flight mechanics, eigenvalues of the stability matrix determine the stability modes of an aircraft. The determinant of a system matrix indicates its invertibility, which is crucial in control system design and solving linear systems. The property that the product of eigenvalues equals the determinant serves as a quick check in numerical eigenvalue algorithms and provides insight into matrix invertibility (a zero eigenvalue implies a zero determinant).

common_mistakes.mistake: Calculating individual eigenvalues and then multiplying, which is time-consuming and error-prone, instead of using the determinant property.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Students might default to the general method of finding eigenvalues by solving the characteristic equation, not recalling the property that the product of eigenvalues equals the determinant, or trying to verify by actual eigenvalue computation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember the fundamental property: product of eigenvalues = determinant. Always check if a direct property can be applied before resorting to the full characteristic equation method.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes valuable exam time and increases the risk of calculation errors, potentially leading to a wrong answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrect calculation of the 3x3 determinant due to sign errors or arithmetic mistakes.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing through the determinant expansion, misplacing signs in the cofactor formula, or making arithmetic mistakes due to the multiple multiplications and subtractions involved in 3x3 determinant calculation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write the determinant formula clearly step-by-step. Double-check each multiplication and sign. Practice determinant calculations, and consider using Sarrus' rule as an alternative for 3x3 matrices.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an incorrect numerical answer, likely matching one of the distractors, resulting in negative marks in GATE.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming the matrix is triangular and taking the product of diagonal entries, or confusing the product of eigenvalues with the sum of eigenvalues (trace).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Misreading the matrix or overgeneralizing the property that eigenvalues of a triangular matrix are the diagonal entries, or mixing up the fundamental properties of product of eigenvalues (determinant) and sum of eigenvalues (trace) under exam pressure.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Clearly distinguish and memorize both properties: Product of eigenvalues = Determinant, Sum of eigenvalues = Trace. Always check if the matrix is actually triangular before assuming eigenvalues are diagonal entries.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an incorrect answer, potentially selecting a distractor like the trace (sum of diagonal elements) or the product of diagonal elements if the matrix is mistakenly assumed to be triangular.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting that the property holds only for eigenvalues counted with algebraic multiplicity, and mistakenly using geometric multiplicity.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between algebraic and geometric multiplicity concepts.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall that the characteristic polynomial's roots (including repeats) are the eigenvalues, and the determinant is the constant term (up to sign) of that polynomial.
common_mistakes.consequence: May not affect this problem but could cause issues in defective matrix scenarios.

mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When asked to find the product of eigenvalues or needing to recall the relationship quickly.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Trace of matrix = sum of eigenvalues, Determinant = product of eigenvalues.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Remember both main eigenvalue-matrix relations together.

flashcards.front: What is the relationship between the determinant of a square matrix and its eigenvalues?
flashcards.back: The determinant equals the product of all eigenvalues (counted with algebraic multiplicity): $\det(A) = \lambda_1 \lambda_2 \cdots \lambda_n$.

flashcards.front: True or False: The eigenvalues of a triangular matrix are its diagonal entries.
flashcards.back: True. For upper or lower triangular matrices, the eigenvalues are the diagonal elements.

flashcards.front: What is a common pitfall when asked for the product of eigenvalues of a non-triangular matrix?
flashcards.back: Assuming the matrix is triangular and multiplying the diagonal entries. Always verify the matrix structure, or better, use the determinant property directly.

flashcards.front: Given matrix A = [[2,1,1];[1,3,1];[1,1,4]], what is the product of its eigenvalues? (Do not compute eigenvalues individually.)

real_world_context.industry_example: In aircraft wing design, engineers use finite element analysis (FEA) to model the structure. Eigenvalues represent natural frequencies, and their product (related to the determinant of the stiffness matrix) provides insights into the overall system behavior.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Accurate prediction of natural frequencies is crucial to avoid resonance and ensure structural integrity. A zero eigenvalue (determinant zero) indicates a rigid body mode or instability, which is critical for safety.

real_world_context.industry_example: In flight control systems, eigenvalues of the state matrix determine stability. Their product (related to constant term of characteristic polynomial) affects system response.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Engineers can use determinant checks as a quick verification of eigenvalue calculations in simulations.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quick 1-minute question if you recall the determinant-eigenvalue product property. Direct calculation of determinant is straightforward.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, compute the determinant carefully; options are distinct numbers. Avoid guessing 24 (product of diagonals) as it's a common trap.
exam_strategy.time_management: Budget 1-2 minutes max. If stuck, compute determinant via any reliable method.

search_keywords: product of eigenvalues equals determinant proof

alternative_methods.name: Characteristic Polynomial Method / Explicit Eigenvalue Calculation
alternative_methods.description: This method involves forming the characteristic equation $\det(A - \lambda I) = 0$ (or $\det(\lambda I - A) = 0$), where $I$ is the identity matrix and $\lambda$ represents the eigenvalues. For an $n \times n$ matrix, this results in an $n$-th degree polynomial in $\lambda$. The product of the eigenvalues is equal to the constant term (up to sign) of this characteristic polynomial. Alternatively, one can solve the polynomial to find all individual eigenvalues $\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \dots, \lambda_n$ and then multiply them to get the product $\lambda_1 \lambda_2 \dots \lambda_n$.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Systematic, always works, and provides all individual eigenvalues. Cons: Extremely time-consuming for larger matrices in an exam setting, highly prone to algebraic errors when solving the characteristic equation, and generally not recommended for questions specifically asking only for the product or sum of eigenvalues.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When the question explicitly asks for individual eigenvalues or eigenvectors, when no simpler property can be applied, or if the matrix structure makes the characteristic polynomial easy to solve.

alternative_methods.name: Eigenvalue Decomposition
alternative_methods.description: Instead of finding the eigenvalues directly, one can perform eigenvalue decomposition on the matrix A to express it as A = PDP^-1, where D is a diagonal matrix containing the eigenvalues. The determinant can then be calculated as the product of the diagonal elements in D.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Provides more insight into the matrix structure. Cons: Requires additional steps of finding the eigenvectors and transformation matrix P.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When a full matrix decomposition is required for other purposes, such as diagonalization or finding eigenvectors.

connections_to_other_subjects.Vibrations and Structural Dynamics: Eigenvalues represent natural frequencies; product relates to system's overall stiffness and mass distribution.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Theory: Eigenvalues are poles of transfer function; product affects system's characteristic equation constant term.
connections_to_other_subjects.Numerical Methods: Determinant and eigenvalue algorithms often use this property for verification. Many numerical algorithms for finding eigenvalues (e.g., QR algorithm, power method) also rely on matrix properties and transformations.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Eigenvalues of the system matrix determine the stability and dynamic response of a control system. The determinant of the system matrix is related to its invertibility and controllability.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Eigenvalues of the stability derivatives matrix are used to determine the longitudinal and lateral-directional stability modes of an aircraft (e.g., phugoid, short period, spiral, roll convergence, Dutch roll).
connections_to_other_subjects.Linear Algebra: The relationship between eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and the determinant is a fundamental concept in linear algebra with applications across engineering disciplines.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structural Dynamics: Eigenvalue analysis is used to determine the natural frequencies and mode shapes of mechanical systems, which is crucial for vibration analysis and design.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structures: Eigenvalues are used in modal analysis to find natural frequencies and mode shapes of vibrating structures. The determinant of the dynamic stiffness matrix is crucial in identifying these frequencies.

deeper_dive_topics: Spectral Theorem for symmetric matrices (this matrix is symmetric, so eigenvalues are real).
Relationship between trace and sum of eigenvalues: $\text{tr}(A) = \sum \lambda_i$.
Cayley-Hamilton Theorem: matrix satisfies its own characteristic polynomial.
Applications in principal component analysis (PCA) for data reduction in aerospace sensor data.
